Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2010 02:01PM pookie61 wrote: Many congratulations to you and everyone with good scan results.  Take care.
Posts.Title: Taxol + Avastin = Love with the Stable Boy! LC815 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 06:32PM pookie61 wrote: I think all of us understand what you mean.  I have times where I just want to get ths over with as soon as possible because it seems too overwhelming to keep going.  So much pain, anguish and terror on a daily basis for me.  But all of the days have good parts about them that remind me why I am fighting this battle and not just opting out.  I have two miserable teenagers but just being able to give them a hug, make them dinner and scream at them even is enough.  Just being able to cuddle with my hubby at nite. (sex?).  My husband is not in denial, but my parents are big time.  Especially my mom.  My dad does not even like to talk to me anymore.  But his mom and his sister both died of cancer, so I understand to a point. Marybe, thanks for sharing your story.  I found it to be full of hope.  I am hopeful, but for me it has to be a realistic kind of hope.  Now I wish for five more years to see my daughter graduate high school.  When I was first diagnosed I never dreamed this goal would be so hard to achieve. Take care.
Posts.Title: Scans say stable. I say big deal. LynnW Dollyd

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2009 05:44AM pookie61 wrote: I have been on both of these drugs for about 6 months and I find the combo very doable.  The Zometa will give me some flu like symptoms and bone pain for about two days after infusion.  I am now seeing some side effects with the femara-mainly feeling like I am 100 for a while when I get up.  But once I get up and moving I am Ok, and I take advil if it is worse.  Sometimes I take a small dose of Vicodin.   Overall, very doable and great results so far.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 11:12AM pookie61 wrote: Barbe,  My point is that it really does not matter what your intentions are.  However, as we see with the other people that are stage iv that have posted in this thread, they seem to feel that it isn't safe or secure for them to post here as much anymore.  Like I said, I am not saying that the intentions of those who post here are not entirely good and honorable.  I am sure that they are. But that is all besides the point.  Some of us want a place where we can just be stage iv.  Obviously we can't keep others from reading.  I prefer though, that other stages post in all of the other forums that are available to them.  You always have the option of pm's, chatting, phone calls, etc. if you want to keep in contact with other people more personally.  A thread is not the place for a private conversation. I have said enough and have made my point.  Selfishlessly I want our own place.  Forgive my bluntness, but frankly I don't care about your rosy colored excuses for invading our turf.
Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 06:20PM pookie61 wrote: I guess I would say to all the non stage 4's who come here-we are not doubting that you have your reasons to be here.  We are not saying those reasons aren't good.  We are asking for a place where we can be together without the rest of you.  This thread shows that some stage 4's aren't posting because of this problem.  This makes me mad.  To all the non stage 4's , I ask, is this what you are trying to accomplish?  Why can't you let us have a place to be ourselves?
Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 05:20AM pookie61 wrote: Elizabeth,  You are not being bitchy.  This subject came up a few months ago as well.  I can understand other stages wanting to post when someone they know is having problems.  To some extent I can understand wanting to read here and be prepared.  However, having been on both sides of the fence I can state that you can't be prepared.  We cannot give you treatment advice because we are not oncologists.  Also, our battles will not prepare you for yours.  You are just scaring yourselves unnecessarily and wasting your precious time.  But we obviously cannot stop other stages from posting either here or on the palliative care section, where the posts irk me more.  So I too have learned to move on, ignore the posts, and respond to what I wish.  Take care Elizabeth and thanks for bringing this up.
Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 04:56PM pookie61 wrote: Welcome JoJo.  I feel like I am here to support everyone regardless of their treatment preferences and decisions.  Often in the eight months since being diagnosed with mets I have thought about not doing treatment, but because my kids are not grown I feel that this is not an option for me.  Things have been so difficult in the last few years even with the treatment I did initially.   Naturally your family will want you to stay around as long as possible.  But even as empathetic as family and friends and even people here can be, noone really knows completely how hard things are for anyone else.  I believe that in the end we have the right to choose what course our lives will take. Feel free to come here anytime to vent, moan, laugh or cry.  We are here to help. Take care.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 03:18PM pookie61 wrote: Watson, Melt down all you want.  It is amazing with all you have been through and are going through that you aren't on any pain or anxiety stuff. I take lexapro for anxiety/antidepressant as well as Vicodin for pain.  Lately I have upped my Vicodin because the pain for my bone mets has gone up quite a bit.  I take a low dose, about 1/4 of a pill, a few times a day to help with the pain and try to avoid being comotose. I think some oncs may be reluctant to prescribed antidepressants and antianxiety.  I go to a shrink for the Lexapro, and get my pain meds from the onc.  Believe me, the headshrinkers will be more than happy to give you everything you need.  Whenever I go back they are trying to get me on yet another pill. I am wordy today.  Take care of yourself and glad you are almost through with rads.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 02:37AM pookie61 wrote: I had a biopsy not just to confirm the bone mets, but also to confim whether the er/pr status had changed.  It was CT guided.  They gave me an IV drug to deal with the pain, but I was still awake.  The procedure was not bad, but they had to work a bit to get the biopsy.  They gave me more pain meds when I said it was still hurting.  Afterward I rested for an hour and went home.  I was back to normal the next day.  Overall, it wasn't bad and I would not start treatment for bone mets w/o a biospy first.  Take care.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 02:15PM pookie61 wrote: I think the answer depends on the person.  Your onc will be able to tell by comparing your tumor markers, scans, and verbal reports of how you are feeling to see how closely your markers track your cancer.  With some the markers are not very reliable.  However, with others, myself included, the markers are an extremely accurate indication of what is going on with my cancer.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 03:03PM pookie61 wrote: I have cleaning help that comes in twice per month and gets the basics done.  I also pay someone to cut my grass once per week.  This summer I have vowed, as I do each summer, that I am going to set up a chore list and have my kids (12 and 15) do more.  Now that I have mets I am planning on requiring each of them to make dinner at least once per week.  I go grocery shopping once per week so they can plan their menu, I will buy the food.  They can make it and I will help. and then they will clean up. Ah-who am I kidding?  Anyway, this is my plan.  See what happens in 2 months. SIGH..

Posts.Title: DNR Paula1628 Padiddle

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 12:20PM pookie61 wrote: Your mother should not be suffering this much from her bone mets.  I have bone mets in many places, as well as liver mets, and most days I don't need any pain medication at all.  It is very possible with bone mets to live a good number of years with a good quality of life.  With all the modern pain medications available, there is absolutely to reason for her to suffer with pain. Several things come to find.  First, it could be that your mother is feeling depressed and overwhelmed.  The depression could be making her pain worse.  She should not be resigned to a poor quality of life.  I know you say she won't join a support group or post here, but maybe if you print out the responses to your post and get her to read them she will feel differently.  If you feel as though her current oncologist is not being responsive to her quality of life issues, it might be time to find someone else.  My oncologist is very concerned with my qol and refuses to allow me to live in pain.  She knows about the reality of this disease and will do anything to ensure my life is as good as possible.  Your mother deserves the same Take care and let us know how she is doing.  I hope you and your mom have a wonderful holiday season.
Posts.Title: The reality of bone mets crazydaughter Mazy1959

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 10:49AM pookie61 wrote: I know that scared people often are looking for reassurance and I don't blame them.  Some of us are prepared to give that, and others cannot, for many reasons.  I also know that it can be overwhelming to try to look up information by yourself if you are scared to death.    I just thought though I would mention that there are great places to do research before you come here and post.  For example, there is another website that I frequent at http://www.bcmets.org.  This site is a listserver and is organized differently.  However, the nice thing about it is that you don't have to be on the list to search the archives.  They have posts dating back a long way.  It is very easy to search and all you need to do is type in your terms.  I have searched there many times for strange symptoms and have never failed to find someone going through the same thing.
Posts.Title: Please don't leave us PT63 EWB

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 01:31PM pookie61 wrote: Cure in our lifetime-no.  Cure in our children's lifetimes-I would love to believe yes.  But I really don't anymore.  I think that this disease is complex and is many diseases.  It seems in some ways that the more they discover the less they realize is actually known.  My real belief and hope is that they continue to find treatments for all types of breast cancers that will prolong our lives with as much quality as possible.   I think that the real chance for a type of cure lies in prevention through vaccines and also from much earlier detection before any of this manages to get into the nodes and/or the bloodstream.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 11:03AM pookie61 wrote: Patti, You are in an incredibly difficult place right now.  I understand what you mean about fooling your onc-I am sure my doctor thinks the same thing.  Everyone is different, but I know i feel like I need to stay upbeat because of kids at home.  To some extent I shield my husband and family because I don't want them to worry so much. There are other chemo options for you to try.  Maybe you and your husband are at a place where either you or both of you need someone else you can really talk to.  It could be anyone who helps you-friends, family, professional, or religous.   For me it really needs to be someone who can both listen to me and help guide me, but not make decisions for me.  Luckily for me my husband's aunt works in a hospice as an aide, and she is so supportive.  She does not try to tell me eveything is going to be all right.  She mainly listens, but occasionally will make a supportive suggestion. You are in my thoughts.  Many hugs as you go through this incredibly difficult time.
Posts.Title: It is a bad sign that I am in my pj's pattih joaniji

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2010 09:10AM pookie61 wrote: I can't do videos either.  I have a paralyzed vocal cord from cancer and hate how I sound now.  Don't much like how I look either, although never was a Ms. America candidate.   I have been keeping a journal for my kids for about a year now.  I write in each one about 1-2 times per week.  Sometimes it is just about what is going on.  But sometimes it gets sappy, as you say.  Last week I had an entry for both kids entited  "the top ten things I love about you."  I just take each day and write what I want. But I have wanted to and have covered certain topics-eg-marriage, kids, husbands, love, a little sex, husband getting remarried, etc. with both kids.  Although sappy I want them to know it is ok with me if they call someone else mom and love someone else this way.  I don't want them to feel guilty about that.  JMO. There is a lot more.  I want to say the hard things in the journal because I don't know if I will remember to say them in person. Take care.
Posts.Title: It is a bad sign that I am in my pj's pattih joaniji

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2010 12:47PM pookie61 wrote: I have had horner's syndrome for about 2 years now, caused by a tumor in the neck area.  Major symptom was that my left eye does not open as much as my right.  I was tested for brain mets with an MRI and spinal mets with a spinal tap.  Thankfully both of those were negative.  I am not getting rads because the tumor causing the problem is too close to the esophagus, so they watch it with scans.  I have not had any other symptoms from the Horner's.  However, I have other neuro issues from this tumor, especially left side vocal cord paralysis.  Take care.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 04:41AM pookie61 wrote: I had a ct guided biopsy of my bone mets.  I would go in the machine, and then come out and a lady with a mallet (sp?) would pound on my back for a while.  The process was repeated a few times.  They gave me some pain meds, but I was awake the whole time.  All in all not too bad despite the description.  In a way it was kind of blackly comical because the technician was this really tiny woman who was pounding on my back with all she had.  It was kind of like a bad cartoon. Anyway, it wasn't bad and was worthwhile because I got important path info on my mets. Take care and good luck.
Posts.Title: biopsy for bone mets vivo joaniji

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 08:29PM pookie61 wrote: Nancy, I have extensive liver mets and have also been experiencing increased pain, although not in the same areas as you.  I think it is great news that you had a good recent scan. I am surprised you take Tylenol for pain, but I don't know if you are on chemo right now.  I am on Taxol and Avastin, and am not allowed to take any pain relievers that mask a fever.  You need more effective pain relief asap.  The problem with the pain is that not only does it affect our physical well being, it takes a huge toll on our emotional well being.  When we are in pain our minds tend to assume the worst, whether true or not.  Since what you are taking is not working, you need something better.  I take dilalid (sp?) which works well for me.  I take a small dose, and it works great.  No side effects except a small amt. of constipation.  When my liver pain starts to kick in, I take one.  Not only does the physical pain go away, but I stop worrying about the cancer.  This is very helpful to me. If you have something stronger in the house, take it.  Don't waste time being in pain!  If you don't, it is time to call the on call onc and maybe get something stronger.  Maybe they can get in touch with you onc who can call something in.  Otherwise you might have to get through the weekend or go to the ER for better pain relief. But I would get some better pain relief soon.  Take care and let us know how you feel.
Posts.Title: Twinges turn to pain turn to anxiety nancyh tami444

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 10:25PM pookie61 wrote: I am not sure I get the point entirely.  But to me you bring up a good point about the value of laughter in our lives.  I never noticed that I wasn't laughing nearly as much as before until my husband mentioned it the other night.  He said how good it was to hear me laugh with my daugther.  I realized he was right.  It seems so hard for me to laugh at all, at anything.  I don't think our situations are funny.  But I know laughing makes me feel better.  I like the idea of a laughing yoga class, and would like to try it sometime.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 06:14AM pookie61 wrote: I don't know what to hope for anymore.  Sometimes I actually can feel positive that maybe something will come along.  Then other thoughts creep in.  I have been trying to find a way to hope in a way that works for me.  I will focus on an upcoming summer vacation, and look forward to that.  Or I will focus on even a smaller period of time, and hope that I will feel good during the coming day or week.  I still don't have this down, and doubt that I ever will.  To maintain my sanity I need to find something positive to hope for.  At the same time, I make sure that I write in the journals I am keeping for my kids at least a few times a week.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 09:25AM pookie61 wrote: I have the same problem.  Except the thoughts seem to be accompanied by weird physical symptoms, which can really freak me out. My answer at this point is ativan, a small amount of alchohol during dinner, and exercise during the day.  I don't get up because it disturbs my husband, who also has trouble sleeping.  One odd thing that helps me is concentrating on the noise of my hubby's cpap machine.  He took it with us on our recent trip to Cancun, so now I associate it with the trip and the ocean.  It can help.  I am thinking about getting something that sounds like the ocean to play all night. Hoping you can get some restful sleep soon.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2010 02:59PM pookie61 wrote: I just wonder if your doctors really know how miserable you are.  I doubt that diet will take care of the problem if you have already tried other meds.  There are prescription drugs that your onc can give you that might help.  I might insist on getting the ascites drained.  Other women on this board and other boards  that I have read about with liver mets, bad constiptation and ascites have seemed to need them drained for relief.  You should not be suffering this much.  Hope you get some relief soon.
Posts.Title: Ascites and Constipation Relief - Advice desparately needed mason204 MCTHO

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 10:56AM pookie61 wrote: I am a patient at M.D Anderson.  There are good and bad things about going to such a large institution.  In terms of treatment, I am not getting anything that different.  However, it might give you and your parents peace of mind.  I am wondering though why you are not considering Memorial Sloan Kettering in NY, which is also supposed to be excellent.  Take are.
Posts.Title: Have you been to MD Anderson? bmdaley KarmaKittie

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 02:23PM pookie61 wrote: I go the gym as much as possible, because I love being active.  It usually works out to about 4-5 times per week, since I am not working.  I have fairly extensive bone and liver mets, but luckily I have no restrictions on my activity.  It makes me feel more normal.  I have modified my cardio to mainly treadmill, elliptical, or water aerobics.  I also do some careful weight training.  If you have questions you could check with your onc first.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Anyone Stage IV still going to the gym? Lynn1 KSkier
